Persian Constitutional Revolution: a nationalistic coalition of merchants, religious leaders and intellectuals in Persia forces the shah to grant a constitution and establish a national assembly, the Majlis.
The SS Valencia strikes a reef off Vancouver Island, Canada, killing over 100 (officially 136) in the ensuing disaster.
Ecuador-Colombia earthquake (8.8 on the Moment magnitude scale) and associated tsunami.
HMS Dreadnought is launched and sparks the naval race between Britain and Germany.
Pope Pius X publishes the encyclical Vehementer Nos denouncing the 1905 French law on the Separation of the Churches and the State.
Courrières mine disaster: an explosion in a coal mine in France kills 1,060.
Traian Vuia makes a short flight in a self-propelled, heavier-than-air aircraft.
Mount Vesuvius erupts and devastates Naples.
The Azusa Street Revival, the primary catalyst for the revival of Pentecostalism this century, opens in Los Angeles.

San Francisco earthquake (estimated magnitude 7.8) on the San Andreas Fault destroys much of San Francisco, California, USA, killing at least 3,000, with 225,000-300,000 left homeless, and $350 million in damages.
In Tsarist Russia, the Fundamental Laws are announced at the first state Duma.
Karl Staaff steps down as Prime Minister of Sweden over the issue of expanded voting rights. He is replaced by the right-wing naval officer and public official, Arvid Lindman.
Cunard liner RMS Lusitania is launched in Glasgow as the world's largest ship.
Alfred Dreyfus is exonerated. He is reinstalled in the French Army on July 21, thus ending the Dreyfus affair.
The first Imperial German Navy submarine, U-1, is launched.
A magnitude 8.2 earthquake in Valparaíso, Chile leaves approximately 20,000 dead.
The first Victor Victrola, a phonographic record player, is manufactured.
Unable to control a rebellion Cuban President Tomás Estrada Palma requests United States intervention. The subsequent provisional occupation administration lasts until 1909.
Mahatma Gandhi coins the term Satyagraha to characterize the Non-Violence movement in South Africa.
A typhoon and tsunami kill an estimated 10,000 in Hong Kong.
The first Gordon Bennett Cup in ballooning is held, starting in Paris. The winning team, piloting the balloon United States, lands in Fylingdales, Yorkshire, England.
The Grand Duchy of Finland becomes the first nation to include the right of women to stand as candidates when it adopts universal suffrage.
The Majlis of Iran convenes for the first time.
A United States diplomatic crisis with Japan arises when the San Francisco public school board orders Japanese students to be taught in racially segregated schools.
Imposter Wilhelm Voigt impersonates a Prussian officer and takes over the city hall in Köpenick for a short time.
An aeroplane of Alberto Santos-Dumont takes off at Bagatelle in France and flies 60 meters (200 feet). This is the first officially recorded powered flight in Europe.
The Union Minière du Haut Katanga, a Belgian mining trust, is created in the Congo.
SOS becomes an international distress signal.
Russian Prime Minister Pyotr Stolypin introduces agrarian reforms aimed at creating a large class of land-owning peasants.
Reginald Fessenden makes the first radio broadcast: a poetry reading, a violin solo, and a speech.
The world's first feature film, The Story of the Kelly Gang, is released.
